Bringing The Outside In: The untold secrets of plants

16/06/2022

Lucy Cooper talks to York-based plant shop about how plants can help student mental health

Image by Lucy Cooper

By Hannah Carley

Tucked on a side street just a stoneâ€™s throw away from the train station, is a little green paradise â€“ filled to the brim with leafy plant goodness. When stepping into The Outside In, you are greeted by a calming, quiet sanctuary away from the busy road outside. â€œShould I put the kettle on?â€ shop owner Alice calls from the back room, bringing out a selection of brews and herbal teas. After settling on a builderâ€™s tea, we get down to business, as I admire the ever growing jungle around us.

When I first encountered The Outside In earlier this year, I was attending a private terrarium workshop, where Alice taught us how to create the perfect miniature garden. It still stands pride of place on my bookshelf, a mini-ecosystem filled with plants, stones and crystals.

Since then, The Outside In has continued to push these workshops, delving into the world of joint sessions with different therapeutic partners and plant still life drawing evenings. It all proves one thing; just as it is emblazoned onto the window of the shop â€“ everything is about â€œliving better with plantsâ€.

There is no doubt that plants are an essentialpart of our lives, and as students, we can use them to improve our day to day wellbeing and mental health. Having something to look after and to love is particularly good for mental health â€“ to â€œsee something thriving helps you thriveâ€, as Alice enthusiastically argues when I ask what is so special about plants and wellbeing. As humans,we also have an innate feeling of needing to be around greenery, and particularly in the bleaker winter months, owning plants can help lift those low spirits.

Studies have shown how connecting with soil can be key â€“ with the handling of soil releasing serotonin â€“ which Alice tries to incorporate in her workshops through dedicated sessions focusing on making things like mud pies alongside clayworks of art. Especially important is the air purification that plants can offer. As students, this proves par-icularly useful. A houseplant often takes pride of place in a small university accommodation room, and thus can prove useful for pumping out oxygen as we sleep â€“ or, as we sit and work on deadlines overnight.

It seems clear that plants are an importantway to improve our wellbeing, but what should a student consider when delving into the house plant world? Alice focuses on the importance of finding the perfect plant to match to each situation. In fact, her interest in plants piqued as a child when she discovered the idea of position and place. This theory involves selecting parts of the garden to fill with plants that would thrive in that specific spot. The same principle can be applied inside the home with houseplants too. As she explains to meover our cups of tea, â€œsome people want plants they can love and fuss overâ€, in which case a succulent would be no use. It is essential to consider what you truly want from your plant and how much attention you are willing to give it.

But regardless, there are some necessities that apply to all students. For many, there is the possibility of moving time after time â€“ so plants that can be transported easily, and can adapt to temperature and environment changes are a must. A good air filtering process, as mentioned above, is another key thing to consider when caring foryour plant.

Thus, a fool proof option is a snake plant, known by plant aficionados as sansevieria. Their distinctive yellow edged leaves are â€œfantasticâ€ for coping with different light conditions â€“ just needing their water intake to be adjusted accordingly. They are very tolerant of drought, so they can be left over the university holidays and survive the month no problem. Of course, they also produce oxygen overnight, unlike other more leafier, softer plants that pump out carbon dioxide instead. In the 1980s, NASA worked on a study considering plants and how they filter out harmful toxinsand pollutants from the air. Their study placed snake plants in their top ten most airfiltering plants, with their ability to filter multiple toxins from sources including paper, plastics, rubber and paints.

But once the plant is secured, and has found its space on your bedroom shelves, how can a student ensure it is looked after? Of course, being in the right lighting with the right amount of water is key.

When I asked Alice for advice, she also hadsome top tips for the holidays â€“ recognising that there are hacks to keep them happy whilst you are temporarily away. A wicking technique is perhaps the easiest; just grab a pot of water and put one end of some string in the water, with the other fedinto the soil. Not only is it a handy science experiment, but it should tide some plants over until you can arrive back to York to give them a little extra TLC.

Advice giving is something that the owner ofÂ  The Outside In does well. When I asked about Covid, it was clear that there has been a clear up-take in houseplant love after the pandemic. Alice agrees â€“ there has been a definite increase in plant sales, and her houseplant doctor services are becoming ever more essential, as more and more people struggle to continue their upkeep after they first got into the plant life in lockdown. She teaches people how to repot their plants and care for them in different seasons. This post-pandemic recognition of the importance of plants is clear within Aliceâ€™s mission.

During Covid times, she began to realise that people were going to be in great need when coming out of lockdowns to reconnect and heal from these times, and she spent furlough considering how she could use her plant skills to help that. The unit along Holgate Road became available, and soon Alice turned it into an exciting multi-purpose space â€“ one of a workshop that can be used to invite people in, with its role as a shop coming second.

Workshops have become a key part of The Outside Inâ€™s offering, making the most of the benefits that being around plants can bring â€“ grounding you in an environment surrounded by plants. Aliceâ€™s aim is to help people spend time with plants; learning about their roots, getting their hands in the soil and the moss â€“ literally connecting with the plants as you are guided through it. When I made my terrarium a few months ago, I noticed exactly that â€“ the chance to build your own little garden, using your own creativity to delve into the soil and pick out the perfect foliage. Once again, it proves how plants can support our wellbeing.

Not only that, but it is evident that the workshops offer a space for calm and reflection. You take very little notice of your phone whilst you are there, and have the chance to be digitally disconnected; a modern rarity.

There is the opportunity to take time to yourself and reconnect with nature.Â  As Alice says to me on this sunny May morning, â€œplants do everything slowly, so they have a lot to teach usâ€. This reflection is seen throughout the workshops developed by Alice. Plant drawing workshops are key â€“ all focused on enabling people to come out of lockdown and reconnect with new people, without having to go to the pub or another formal setting. It offers an activity to keep your hands busy, to focus on the details of the plant and avoid direct eye contact, whilst striking up conversation with those around you. Since their introduction, the workshops have helped participants sleep, relax, and find time for themselves in their very busy lives, Alice tells me.

I was particularly interested in the joint workshops appearing within Aliceâ€™s little plant unit. She tells me about a therapeutic one coming up, aptly named Feet in Clay, Hands in Mud â€“ where you use clay as a therapeutic tool to connect with, whilst then going on to work with soil and plants. For students, there is no doubt that the workshops can prove exciting, and a clear way to take a step back from the intense experiences of essay deadlines and late night revision that dictate university life. Alice offers private sessions for two to eight people, which are a great way to connect with loved ones, housemates and course friends. Bring a bottle along, have a party, and come away with your own terrarium. For Â£40 per person, itâ€™s an investment well worth making, with mine still growing into new shapes everyday.

When I asked Alice where she saw The Outside In going from here, it was clear the goal is to keep growing and moving forward, and to make sure it is accessible to everyone with different budgets, needs, and different spaces.

The very focus of the unique little plant shop down Holgate road was to allow people time with plants who might not have outdoor spaces. This emphasis on accessibility is something that Alice is going to keep pushing, through things like a continuous course teaching people how to work with their plants indoors.

It is evident that The Outside In is only going to keep growing, and keep changing up their offerings to ensure everyone can live better with plants.

As students, we can learn a lot from the shop and its goals. Incorporating plants into a way of improving our day-to-day wellbeing, whether it be through scientific air-purification, or by the very existence of something to love and look after. By picking the perfect plant, we can make our day to day lives just that little bit more pleasant.

To book a workshop or find out more about The Outside In, visit their Instagram @theoutsideinyork
